markdown.label: Professional Experience
markdown.markdown:
[37m [0m[35m[1mChief of Counter-bullshit operations[0m[0m, Gandi.net | October 2013 to December 2015, San Francisco [33mAKA developer advocate, technical community manager, support automation specialist, chaos monkey [0m I interacted with various tech communities, online and at industry events, letting developers know we exist, helping them make the most of Gandi's domain, SSL and hosting APIs, and communicating their feedback to our technical team. Internally, I worked with engineers, product managers and support to improve Gandi's APIs, web interface, documentation and open source presence.
Job responsibilities included:
* [1mOutreach[0m, both online and in person (at tech conferences and industry events), helping existing and prospective customers to make the most of Gandi's products (domain names, SSL certs, hosting, and the corresponding APIs); * [1mLocalization[0m: Technical and marketing communications (product releases, newsletters, announcement, outages); * [1mDocumentation[0m: Creating and editing tutorials and docs * [1mCommunication[0m: Helping shape Gandi's voice our blog posts, newsletters and social media interactions, organize events and manage our supported projects. * [1mCommunity[0m: Cultivating a [thriving and enthusiastic community](https://twitter.com/gandibar/favorites). * [1mSpecial projects[0m: Being ready for anything.
[35m[1mSupport representative[0m[0m, Gandi.net | February 2012 to October 2013, Lawrence, KS
My original role at Gandi was entry-level support: troubleshooting and explaining issues relating to domain names, DNS, SSL certificates and basic hosting. My curiosity and interest in this role led me to specialize in more technical hosting issues, while helping to hire, train and mentor new employees. My French language and community-related skills led me to move to San Francisco to take on an official evangelism role in 2013.
[35m[1mPrevious positions[0m[0m: See LinkedIn profile

markdown.label: Unprofessional Experience
markdown.markdown:
I've danced myself into a trance in Berlin nightclubs and Haitian RaRas. I've seen the inside of several jail cells. I tried to burn a bra once but it wouldn't catch.
I've organized underground newspapers, backyard boxing leagues and protests, as well as several successful dinner parties.
If working for your company will help me expand this section, please reach out ASAP.

markdown.label: [Experience] Gandi.net
markdown.markdown: [37m [0m Employer [32mGandi.net[0m Location [32mSan Francisco, CA[0m Dates [32mFebruary 2012 to December 2015[0m 2013-2015 [33m[1m[7mChief of counter-bullshit operations[0m A.K.A. [32mDeveloper advocate API evangelist Technical community manager Chaos monkey Emergency communication strategist Open source champion Automation specialist Special projects QA intern Workshop administrator Swag dealer[0m 2012-2013 [33m[1m[7mLevel 1 Support Agent[0m A.K.A. [32mSupport ticket answerer person Documentation tweaker Bug hunter Twitter person Question asker[0m

markdown.label: Details
markdown.markdown:
[37m [0m
I interacted with various tech communities, online and at industry events, connecting with developers and helping them make the most of Gandi's domain, SSL and hosting APIs.
I was the primary technical contact for Gandi resellers in the U.S., escalating to the CTO where appropriate.
Internally, I worked with engineers, product managers and support to improve Gandi's APIs, web interface, documentation and open source presence based on feedback collected from the community.
I shaped much of Gandi's voice via blog posts, newsletters and social media interactions. I created, edited and localized a wide variety of technical documentation, emergency communications and product communications.
I guided and managed Gandi's supported initiatives and open source projects, organizing various campaigns and partnerships for our mutual benefit.
I tested and documented a huge number of Gandi's products and features.
Above all, I was ready for anything, which usually happened at least once a day.

markdown.label: TL;DR
markdown.markdown:
[37m [0m My original role at Gandi was entry-level support: troubleshooting and explaining issues relating to domain names, DNS, SSL certs and basic hosting.
My curiosity and interest in this role led me to specialize in more technical hosting issues, while helping to hire, train and mentor new employees, edit blog posts, and generally pitch in anywhere I could be helpful.
This versatility led me to be promoted to a so-called Community Manager role in our new San Francisco office.
From the time I was hired (near the beginning of Gandi's expansion into the U.S.) to the time I left, I had played a role in nearly every aspect of our growth in the United States.
